## Terminology: Space/Spatial

<hr>

::: incremental
::: {.smaller-font .smaller-line-width}
-   What is 'space'?
    -   outer space, physical space, [**geographic space**]{.green}
-   Spatial data
    -   is: data that has a spatial component
        -   geographic boundaries
        -   geographic features
        -   [**geographic coordinates**]{.green}
    -   is not: data that is spatially distributed
        -   Demographic data for each U.S. county
        -   [**NCES locale codes**]{.green} *(e.g., City, Suburb, Town, Rural)*
:::
:::

## Terminology: Advanced STEM

<hr>

::: incremental
::: {.smaller-font .smaller-line-width}
-   What is advanced STEM?
    -   Advanced Secondary STEM
        -   Science
        -   Technology
        -   Engineering
        -   Mathematics
-   Advanced STEM Delivery?
    -   [**Advanced Placement (AP)**]{.green}
    -   [**Project Lead the Way (PLTW)**]{.green}
    -   International Baccalaureate (IB)
    -   Dual Enrollment
:::
:::

## **Frameworks:** Opportunities to Learn

<hr>

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: sectionhead
1 [2 3 4 5]{style="opacity:0.25"}

:::

::: incremental
-   What are the necessary conditions for learning?
    -   [**Opportunities to Learn (OTL):**]{.green} "Affordances for changing participation and practice" [(Greeno & Gresalfi, 2008, p. 172)]{.smaller-font}[^7]
    -   Three conditions[^8]:

        -   Accessibility
        -   [Learner dispositions]{.fragment .semi-fade-out}

[^8]: Norman, D. A. (1988). The psychology of everyday things. Basic Books.}

## ***STEM Success:*** Analytic Approach

<hr>

<br>

::: {incremental}
[$$\hspace{-1.75cm}Y_{ij} = \beta_0 + \beta_1City_{i} + \beta_2Town_{i} + \beta_3RuralFringe_{i} +  \beta_4RuralDistant_{i} + \beta_5RuralRemote_{i} + \\ \beta_6RaceEth_{i} + \beta_7Female_{i} + \beta_8SESDecile_{i} + \alpha_j + \varepsilon_{ij}$$]{.much-smaller-font}

-   [$Y_{ij}$= Predicted APÂ® exam score for the *i* th student in the *j* th state-exam-year fixed effect]{.much-smaller-font}
-   [$City_{i},Town_{i},RuralFringe_{i},RuralDistant_{i},RuralRemote_{i}$= NCES Locale indicator variables for school location]{.much-smaller-font}
-   [$SESDecile_{i}$= Composite SES variable from SEDA, in deciles]{.much-smaller-font}
-   [$RaceEth_{i},Female_{i}$= Binary indicator variables for student demographics]{.much-smaller-font}
-   [$\alpha_{j}$= State by exam by year fixed effects]{.much-smaller-font}
:::

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: sectionhead
[1]{style="opacity:0.25"} 2 [3 4 5]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

-   One logit for each PLTWÂ® Pathway [$$\frac{P_i}{1-P_i} = exp(\beta_{0} + \beta_{1}City_{i} + \beta_{2}Rural_{i} + \beta_{3}Town_{i} + \beta_{4}log(SES)_{i} + \\ \beta_{5}\sqrt{Enrollment}\;_{i} + \beta_{6}log(Prop\;Black)_{i} + \beta_{7}log(Prop\;Latinx)_{i} + \beta_{8}log(Prop\;Asian)_{i} + \alpha_{i}+\epsilon_{i})$$]{.much-smaller-font}
    -   [$P_{i}$= Probability of offering pathway at school *i*]{.much-smaller-font}
    -   [$City_{i},Rural_{i},Town_{i}$= **Locale indicator variables**]{.much-smaller-font}
    -   [$SES_{i}$= Composite SES variable ranging from 0 - 999]{.much-smaller-font}
    -   [$Enrollment_{i}$= Student school population]{.much-smaller-font}
    -   [$Prop\;Black_{i},Prop\;Latinx_{i},Prop\;Asian_{i}$= Proportion of enrollment Black, Latinx, Asian]{.much-smaller-font}
    -   [$\alpha_{i}$= state fixed-effects]{.much-smaller-font}
:::

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: sectionhead
[1 2]{style="opacity:0.25"} 3 [4 5]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

## ***Teacher Learning:*** Context

<hr>

::: {.fragment .smaller-font}
-   Teachers learn from four spheres --- interpersonal, institutional, community, and policy[^17]
-   Within these spheres, teachers learn with learning partners and distributed resources[^18]
-   These partners and tools comprise teachers' [**learning ecologies**]{.green}:

::: custom-blockquote
> *the accessed set of contexts, comprised of configurations of activities, material resources and relationships, found in co-located physical or virtual spaces that provide opportunities for learning* (Barron, 2004, p.6)[^19]
:::
:::

[^17]: Zavelevsky, E., & Lishchinsky, O. S. (2020). An ecological perspective of teacher retention: An emergent model. *Teaching and Teacher Education, 88*, 1-11.

[^18]: Pea, R. (1993). Practices of distributed intelligence and designed for education. In G. Salomon (Ed.), *Distributed cognitions: Psychological and educational considerations* (pp. 47-87). Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press.

[^19]: Barron, B. (2004). Learning ecologies for technological fluency: Gender and experience differences. *Journal of Educational Computing Research, 31* (1), 1-36.

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: sectionhead
[1 2 3]{style="opacity:0.25"} 4 [5]{style="opacity:0.25"}
:::
:::

## **Research Agenda**

<hr>

::: {layout="[5,5,5]"}
::: center
[**Learning Ecosystems**]{.fragment .smaller-font .purple}

::: {.fragment .much-smaller-font}
-   What resources characterize regional STEM learning ecosystems?
    -   How does resource availability and quality vary across communities?
    -   To what extent does the regional presence of resources, institutions, and industry predict local STEM learning outcomes?
-   How does human mobility and community resource exposure shape local STEM learning outcomes?
    -   How does human mobility and resource exposure vary across geographies?
-   How do student learners engage with their local STEM learning ecosystems?
    -   Teacher learners?
:::
:::

::: center
[**Spatial Equity**]{.fragment .smaller-font .purple}

::: {.fragment .much-smaller-font}
-   Which high-leverage resources are most inequitably distributed across space?
    -   How might we amplify the reach of these resources to additional geographic areas?
-   Which regions have strong STEM learning ecosystems? weaker ecosystems?
    -   How might we leverage configurations of and learnings from strong ecosystems to strengthen weak ecosystems?
-   Who are the key knowledge brokers within regional spatial social networks for STEM learning?
    -   How does boundary-crossing by knowledge brokers into neighboring regional networks impact STEM ecosystem health?
:::
:::

::: center
[**Data Science as Tool**]{.fragment .smaller-font .purple}

::: {.fragment .much-smaller-font}
-   Which ideas, skills, and practices are most important for students to learn in data science?
    -   How might we support teachers in facilitating this learning?
-   What data science literacies (including ethics) are critical for students to learn in an age of AI and data science democratization?
-   How might data science ideas, skills, and practices be distributed vertically (across grade levels) and horizontally (across disciplines) in K-12 education?
-   How might we support administrators, teachers, and other stakeholders to leverage data science in improving student outcomes? community outcomes?
:::
:::
:::

::: {.absolute top="0" left="100%"}
::: sectionhead
[1 2 3 4]{style="opacity:0.25"} 5
:::
:::

## **Research Proposal**

<hr>

[***Regional Ecosystems to Support K-12 CS Education***]{.smaller-font}

[**Research Questions:**]{.fragment .green .smaller-font}<br>

::: {.fragment .smaller-font .smaller-line-height}
1.  [What resources and learning partners characterize a regional K-12 CS education learning ecosystem?]{.fragment .smaller-font .smaller-line-height}
    i)  [Which institutions and individuals are the key hubs and bridges in the network?]{.fragment .smaller-font .smaller-line-height}
2.  [How do students and teachers engage with the ecosystem?]{.fragment .smaller-font .smaller-line-height}
:::

[**Methods:**]{.fragment .purple .smaller-font}<br>

::: {.fragment .smaller-font .smaller-line-height}
-   [Participatory asset mapping ]{.fragment .smaller-font .smaller-line-height}[^24], Spatial social network analysis [^25], GIS story maps [^26]
:::

[^24]: [Elwood, S. (2011). Participatory approaches in GIS and society research: Foundations, practices, and future directions. In *The SAGE Handbook of GIS and Society* (pp. 381-399). SAGE.]{.fragment .smaller-font .smaller-line-height}

[^25]: Andris, C., & Sarkar, D. (2022). Social networks in space. In S. J. Rey & R. Franklin (Eds.), *Handbook of Spatial Analysis in the Social Sciences* (pp. 400-415). Elgar.

[^26]: Lung-Amam, W. S., & Dawkins, C. (2019). The power of participatory story mapping: Advancing equitable development in disadvantaged neighbourhoods. *Community Development Journal, 55*(3), 473-495.

## **Long-Term Research Goals**

<hr>

<br>

1.  To [**make visible spatial inequities**]{.green} in STEM learning opportunities
2.  To support [**high-quality STEM experiences for all learners**]{.purple}, particularly in regions of inopportunity
3.  To move toward the realization of [**spatial justice**]{.orange} --- *spatial equity in the distribution of resources and opportunities* --- [**for all learners**]{.orange}
